title: 109_hr450
content: The Act is titled the "National Science Education Incentive Act of 2005" and includes findings. The Congress finds that the United States must maintain its position in science and technology to advance human understanding and improve lives. Over half of the US economic growth is attributed to research and development in science and technology. The growth of the United States today is directly linked to research and development in science and technology. Fundamental research explores the universe and seeks answers to new questions, while applied research applies these answers to real-world problems. The effectiveness of promoting economic growth in the US depends on intellectual capital and innovation, with education playing a critical role in developing these resources. The United States' economic growth relies on intellectual capital and innovation, with education being crucial in developing these resources. The country needs scientists, engineers, technologically proficient workers, and scientifically literate voters and consumers to drive research, development, and success in a science-based, high-technology workplace. The United States relies on research and development for economic growth, requiring technologically proficient workers and scientifically literate individuals. Student performance in math and science shows shortcomings in K-12 education compared to other countries, emphasizing the need for improved teaching methods in these subjects. The current state of K-12 science and mathematics education in the United States requires new teaching methods, improved curricula, better teacher training, and strong parental involvement. Science education should focus on inquiry, experimentation, and concept-based learning. Science education should be hands-on and focused on the scientific process, starting at an early age and continuing throughout school. Teachers play a crucial role in connecting students with the content they are learning. High-quality teachers should be recruited by offering a respected and rewarding career. Teachers are essential in connecting students with the content they learn. Recruiting high-quality teachers who are knowledgeable in their subject area and up-to-date on teaching techniques is crucial for superior results in education. Incentives and ongoing training are necessary to retain teachers in the classroom and improve their practice. A new section, SEC. 36, provides a refundable credit for undergraduate tuition paid by certain teachers. A new section, SEC. 36, offers a refundable credit for qualified undergraduate tuition paid by eligible teachers, with a limit of $1,000. Teachers in high-needs school districts may receive up to $1,500 in the first 5 taxable years. The new section SEC. 36 provides a refundable credit for eligible teachers in elementary or secondary schools, with a limit of $1,500 instead of $1,000. The credit is allowed for up to 10 years for full-time teachers. The new section SEC. 36 offers a refundable credit of up to $1,500 for eligible full-time teachers in grades kindergarten through 12th. Eligible teachers must primarily teach math, science, engineering, or technology courses in grades 9 through 12 or kindergarten through 8. The new section SEC. 36 provides a refundable credit of up to $1,500 for eligible full-time teachers in grades kindergarten through 12th who primarily teach math, science, engineering, or technology courses. Teachers must have a degree in mathematics, science, engineering, or technology and be highly qualified. School administrative functions are also considered as teaching courses. The term 'qualified undergraduate tuition' refers to qualified higher education expenses for enrollment at an institution of higher education. School administrative functions can be treated as teaching courses if they relate to such courses or are for a school focusing on them. The term 'qualified undergraduate tuition' refers to qualified higher education expenses for enrollment at an institution of higher education as defined in the Higher Education Act of 1965. The Secretary will prescribe regulations to carry out the purposes of this section. Conforming amendments are made to section 1324(b) of title 31, United States Code. Conforming amendments are made to section 1324(b) of title 31, United States Code by inserting "or 36" after "section 35". Amendments are also made to the table of sections for subpart C of part IV of subchapter A of chapter 1 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Sec. 36 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 adds provisions for tuition for undergraduate education of certain teachers. The effective date for these amendments applies to taxable years beginning after the enactment of the Act. STEM service contributions refer to the amount paid for STEM services provided in the United States or in the defense dependents' education system. The term 'STEM service contributions' refers to the amount paid for STEM services provided in the United States or in the defense dependents' education system for the exclusive benefit of students at specific schools. 'STEM inventory property' includes property contributions to schools meeting certain criteria. The term 'STEM inventory property' refers to property contributions to schools needed for education in science, technology, engineering, or mathematics in grades K-12. 'STEM services' are services needed by schools for education in these areas. The term 'STEM services' refers to services needed by schools for education in science, technology, engineering, or mathematics in grades K-12. The term 'defense dependents' education system' refers to the program established under the Defense Dependents' Education Act of 1978. STEM teacher externship expenses are amounts paid for a STEM externship program for eligible STEM teachers. The term 'STEM externship program' refers to a program established by a taxpayer in science, technology, engineering, or mathematics areas where eligible STEM teachers receive training to enhance their teaching skills. Eligible STEM teachers are individuals teaching in grades K-12 at educational organizations in the United States. The term 'eligible STEM teacher' refers to any K-12 teacher at a school in the US or on a US military base, teaching science, technology, engineering, or mathematics. STEM teacher training expenses are amounts paid by a taxpayer in STEM fields. The term 'STEM teacher training expenses' refers to amounts paid by a taxpayer in science, technology, engineering, or mathematics fields for the participation of eligible STEM teachers in training programs enhancing their teaching skills. No double benefit deduction is allowed for expenses claimed under this section. The STEM teacher training expenses refer to payments for eligible teachers in science, technology, engineering, or mathematics fields to enhance their teaching skills. No double benefit deduction is allowed for expenses claimed under this section. Amendments have been made to allow a new credit for elementary and secondary STEM contributions. The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years beginning after the enactment of this Act. Nothing in this Act allows the US government to control the curriculum or personnel of any educational institution.
